summary: This is a court order from Judge Loretta Preska denying Ghislaine Maxwell's request for a three-week stay of the unsealing process in a civil case. Maxwell claimed to have 'critical new information' related to both the civil action and her pending criminal case, but the court denied the stay because the information was subject to a protective order in the criminal case and could not be disclosed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Defendant in both the civil case (15 Civ. 7433) and the criminal case (U.S. v. Maxwell, No. 20 Cr. 330). She requested a stay of the unsealing process based on 'critical new information' subject to a protective order.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge who issued this order, denying Maxwell's request for a stay of the unsealing process.

connections.description: Judge Preska is presiding over the civil case in which Maxwell is the defendant and issued this order denying her request.

events.title: Court denies Maxwell's stay request
events.description: Judge Loretta Preska denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request for a three-week stay of the unsealing process in the civil case.

events.title: Court order on unsealing process
events.description: The court issued an order regarding methods for streamlining the unsealing process and determining the next set of docket entries to review.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell requested a three-week stay of the unsealing process citing 'critical new information' related to both the civil and criminal cases against her.
Judge Loretta Preska denied the stay because the information was subject to a protective order in the criminal case and Maxwell was not at liberty to disclose it.
The court indicated Maxwell could renew her request if the protective order in the criminal action was modified to permit disclosure.
The document references two ongoing legal proceedings: the civil case (15 Civ. 7433) and the criminal case (U.S. v. Maxwell, No. 20 Cr. 330).
